data.awards:
• Emeritus Professor, Asian Institute of Technology (AIT), Bangkok, Thailand
    Emeritus Professor title was bestowed upon Prof. Ajit by AIT in recognition of his outstanding academic contribution during his 24 years of tenure at Asian Institute of Technology during 1994-2018.

  • Alexander von Humboldt Foundation Award
    Every year, Alexander von Humboldt (AvH) Foundation grants over 500 research fellowships and awards to highly qualified scholars and scientists of all nationalities on worldwide competitive basis, enabling them to undertake period of research in Germany. Details about AvH Foundation and its activities are available on http://www.avh.de/en/ Prof. Ajit was awarded this prestigious fellowship during 1989-1991 to carry out research at Technical University of Berlin, Germany. Being AvH life member offers a number of privileges such as re-invitation to spend limited period in Germany, Humboldt meetings and symposia and privileges to attend international conferences and seminars.

  • Editorial Board of Water Science and Technology
    Prof. Ajit has been on Editorial Board of the international Journal Water Science and Technology published on International Water Association (IWA), London, UK. This appointment was for the period of 3 years during August 1, 2005 to July 31, 2008.

  • Advisory board member the international journal, "Re/Views in Environmental Science and Bio/Technology (RESB)" (2002-2004).
    RESB is a well-known international journal issued by Wageningen University and published by Kluwer Academic Publishers, The Netherlands. Prof. Ajit was on the advisory board of RESB.

  • SERD Research Award
    Prof. Ajit was awarded SERD Research Award in August 1998 by Dean SERD, Professor Chongrak Polprasert in recognition of outstanding research performance in the fields of "Environmental Technology and Management" and "Water and Wastewater Engineering".

  • Coordinator, Asian Regional Research Programme on Environmental Technology (ARRPET)
    This was a prestigious international project funded by Sida and being implemented under the coordinatorship of Prof. Ajit. ARRPET focused on conducting research relevant to major environmental issues in Asian region by institutions involved in Asian countries. As a coordinator of ARRPET, Prof. Ajit was extensively involved in formulation, development and implementation of this prestigious project since its inception in 1998. The project was based on the concept of networking, in which 20 National Research Institutions (NRIs) from 8 Asian countries were involved besides AIT. Countries participating in ARRPET included China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Vietnam and Thailand.

  • Teaching at Danish Technical University (DTU), Denmark
    During years 1999-2002, Prof. Ajit was teaching courses on "Environmental Management and Ethics" as well as "Wastewater Treatment and Management" at DTU for a class of over 50 students in fall semester each year. DTU is a highly reputed university and has international program on Wastewater Treatment and Management. This teaching activity was covered under Danida-funded twinning cooperation between AIT and DTU.

  • Director, AIT-UN Office
    From September 2008 to 2012, Prof. Ajit worked as the Director of AIT-UN Office. The AIT-UN office essentially was a link between AIT and UN agencies for facilitating various activities to be undertaken in the program. The basic function of the office was to assist UN agencies and AIT faculty in preparation of concept papers, budgets, reports, etc. for any proposed activities and to facilitate information flow across the initiatives with UN agencies.

  • Invited Referee by WWTF, Austria, International Funding Agency to review project proposal
    Prof. Ajit was invited by WWTF, Vienna Science and Technology Fund, Austria, to review project proposal entitled "Implementation of molecular biological tools for modeling and simulation of transient nitrification processes in biological wastewater treatment." Proposals were invited from international academia under WWTF "Life Sciences" Call 2005. The evaluation report was submitted to the funding agency in August, 2005.

  • Invitation by UNESCO to present position paper in Brazil
    On invitation by UNESCO, Prof. Ajit gave presentation a position paperon, "Advanced, Appropriate And Affordable Technologies For Domestic Wastewater Treatment And Reuse In Tropical Region" during UNESCO Workshop on Integrated Urban Water Management In Humid Tropics, Iguassu Falls Brazil, April, 2005.

  • Invitation by Sida to attend project appraisal meeting in Sweden
    In 2005, As the Coordinator of ARRPET, Prof. Ajit was invited by Sida to present aims, objectives, progress and open issues from various ARRPET projects. Based on

data.interests:
My research encompasses highly relevant areas of civil engineering: (1) Soil-Structure interaction (2) Engineering behaviour of unsaturated soils (3) Geotechnical Earthquake Engineering (4) Seismic performance of heritage structures
 
My current research examines the impact of climate change on transportation infrastructure through field monitoring, laboratory testing and numerical modelling. I have also worked on investigating the seismic performance of heritage structures of Nepal. My doctoral research focused on developing a simplified methodology for cost-effective foundation solution espacially piled raft foundation for high-rise buildings/industrial structures subjected to seismic loading.

 

Course Taught at IIT Mandi

Soil Dynamics (CE 560) (August-December 2020, 2021)

Geotechnical Engineering I (CE 302) (February-July 2021)

Geotechnical Engineering II (CE 402) (August-December 2021)

Induction Programme Module- Exploring Engineering  (2020, 2021)

data.activity:
Doctor of Philosophy (As Guide)

  1. Mr. Abhimanyu Sharma, “Contaminant Transport Modelling through slow and fast zones in porous medium”.
    Status: Advance Stage.
    Funded by MHRD
    Abstract: Working on Semianalytical solution of contaminant transport model incorporating near grain boundary layer
    with mobile and immobile regions is the process level investigation modelling approach. Its and experimental and numerical study.
  2. Mr. Aman Chandel, “Suitability of higher modelling approach for contaminant transport through Heterogeneous porous medium”.
    Status: Ongoing.
    Funded by MOES
    Abstract: The thesis is targeted to identify a suitable modeling approach and its limitations for the
    contaminant transport inrandomly heterogeneous porous medium. The estimation of parameters and upscaling
    the modeling for field scale. Its an experimental and numerical study.
  3. Mr. Sahil Sharma, “Contaminant Transport modelling and Aquifer cleansing operation using ANN”.
    Status: Ongoing.
    Funded by MHRD
    Abstract: The uncertainty in the estimation of contaminant transport parameters and the effects
    on aquifer remediation methods, optimization of pumping cycles for real field scenario will be researched.
    It’s a field scale study.

  1. Abhay Guleria, “Solute Transport Modelling through Saturated Porous Media with Time dependent Dispersion”.

Status: Ongoing.
  3. Anurag Sharma, “Extreme Event analysis for Ganga Basin”.  
Status: Ongoing

data.activity:
Field Experience:

Extensive Geological field work in Himalaya from Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Sikkim, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Mizoram; Central India & Delhi.

  • Areas explored in Arunachal Pradesh are from Bhalukpong where MBT is clearly visible, to Tawang where Paro group of rocks (Gneisses) are visible in the N-S transect. While in the E-W trend the places that have been explored are Kameng, Subansiri, Disang and Lohit valley where rocks of Ladakh plutionic groups are also visible.
  • While in Nagaland (From Dimapur to Kohima) and Mizoram, the Sandstones, Siltstones and Shale of Disang, Brail and Tipam are clearly visible along the road transects.
  • Sikkim is the most beautiful place with scenic Tsangpo Lake in eastern side bordering China and Bhutan. Tista flows across various rock types such as Augen Gneisses in Mangan, Rangpo area, Calc-Silicates in Rongli side with copper enrichment in Singtam area and Lingtse gneisses are seen in Gangtok area.
  • Uttarakhand and Himachal area were explored mainly for site selection for hydro electric power plants, dam, weir, HRT, quarry site. Most places along Alaknanda, Bhilangna, Mandakini rivers are covered in Uttarakhand. While in Himachal the geological studies were carried out mostly along Sutlej River. Other places being Manali, Rohtang (both have high grade metamorphic), Keylong, Tandi, Seli, Dugar (Low grade metamorphic).
  • Landslide/ Slope stability studies were carried out in Jammu area from Batote (Mudstones of Muree formations), Prem Nagar (Serichite Schists), Doda (low grade metamorphics), Urnihal (Gneisses), Kishtwar (Lesser Himalaya sequence). GPR and resistivity studies were also carried out on landslides whose total station survey was also done.
  • Field Trip for Ground Water Sampling with on-spot testing with Geophysical surveys, in Chattisgarh, was done from Rajnandgaon (Sandstones), Khairagarh (volcanics), Dongargarh (Granites) Ambagarh Chowki (Genisses), Kaudikasa (Rhyolites), Bodal (Uranium mines in Basaltic terrain), Manpur, Mohla (Igneous rocks) and Kanker.
  • Geophysical, geotechnical, utility, and archaeological mapping in Delhi, Jodhpur, Konark area. GPR survey of Imja lake moraine (Near Mt. Everest base camp), Khumbu region, Nepal.

data.experiences:
Jagadeesh has started his career as Research Fellow at Naval Science and Technological Laboratory (DRDO), Visakhapatnam, in the AUV (defense-class) research group. He contributed to the Variable Buoyancy System mechanical design to enable the efficient, noiseless operation and improve AUV stealth by reducing the thruster operation period. He was actively involved in mechanical drafting, and prototype development. He participated in numerous towing tank experiments and lake trials.

These hands-on experiences led to his foray into marine robotics as a Scientist at the National Institute of Ocean Technology (NIOT) Chennai. He participated in 10 deep-sea research missions (10-45 days sailing) to aid the cyclone and tsunami early warning systems by deploying and maintaining met-ocean moorings and field robots. He was also a part of the subsurface mooring design deployed in the Arctic called ‘IndARC’ mooring.

Jagadeesh completed his Ph.D. entitled “Performance investigations of observation-class and service-class marine robots” from IIT Indore under the supervision of Dr. Santhakumar Mohan, where he designed, developed, and tested two prototypes. As a teaching assistant, he volunteered to mentor undergraduate students in exploring research. Under the Indo-Korean collaborative research, he was a visiting scholar at SNU and Hanyang University, South Korea. His broad research focuses on field robots’ prototyping, mathematical modelling, nonlinear control application on actuator saturation, fault accommodation, and interaction effects. A common thread of his research attempts to understand propulsion techniques using thruster, oscillating fin, and buoyancy to build systems with long-term autonomy and good maneuverability. He was awarded the prestigious ‘IEI Young Engineers Award 2020-21’ from The Institution of Engineers (India) for his efforts in marine technology.

Apart from active research, he has supported student teams for national and international competitions in marine robotics since 2013. He envisions India as a pioneer in marine technology and provides sustainable solutions toward a better tomorrow!

data.interests:
Nanomaterials Science

  • Nanodrugs delivery systems

  • Biosensors

  • Micro porous membranes

A major focus is the study and development of varied drugs delivers systems, particularly engineered lipids, polymers; metal organic frame works.

The Work progress in several areas includes:

  • Creating new approaches for delivering drugs across complex barriers in the body such as the blood-brain barrier.

  • Developing controlled release systems that can be pH, magnetically, temperature, triggered to release drug.

  • Synthesizing new biodegradable polymeric delivery systems which will ultimately be absorbed by the body

  • Studying applications of these systems including the development of effective long-term delivery systems for insulin, cancer and alzimers drugs.

  • Biosensors focused on electrochemical sensors.

  • Energy storage devices.

data.projects:
Ongoing

1. Estimation of Thermal Load on Rocket Base Plate

The rocket base plate is heated by emission of thermal radiation from gases and particles emanating from the convergent-divergent (CD) nozzle. These gases are at high pressure, temperature, mixture of species and contains particles. Thus, accurate estimation of radiation properties of gases and particles, and also efficient solver are necessary to estimation of thermal load on rocket base plate. (MS Thesis: Estimation of Thermal Load on Rocket Base Plate From Exhaust Plume)

2. Estimation of Radiation Losses/Emissions in Combustion Systems

The participating species that are generated during the combustion process emit the radiation energy. This energy leaves the combustion region by radiation mode of heat transfer, i.e., loss of energy, thus causes the reduction in temperature which affects performance of the combustion system. Therefore, emission from each and every species must be accounted for the efficient working of the combustion system (MS Thesis: Estimation of Realistic Radiation Losses/Emissions in Combustion System)

3. Collimated Beam Radiation

In many applications, the energy is transferred in a single direction by radiation mode of heat transfer like, solar energy incident on solar receiver cavity after reflecting from heliostat field. This energy is further traveled from the optical window of the solar receiver cavity through fluid medium to incident on the porous medium. The fluid absorbs-emits and/or scatters radiation energy before energy incident on porous medium. In another application, the solar energy incident on ocean, lakes, ponds travels in the water, gets absorb within water or reaches to the bottom, thus, affects the aquatic life. In another situation, the solar energy incident on the top clouds may affecting its dynamics. Therefore, collimated beam feature developed in our lab could be tuned to study these applications. (PhD Thesis: Interaction of Collimated Beam Radiation with Natural Convection in an Enclosure)

Completed

1. Development of Adaptive Unstructured Angular Discretisation Grid for the Finite Volume Method of Radiative Transfer Equation for Collimated Beam Radiation      

It is a general myth that the radiation heat transfer is only important at very high-temperature applications, however, This is not true. In general, the radiation plays equally important role in the natural convection problems. The radiation heat transfer problems are treated in two ways (1) Surface to Surface radiation (2) Radiation in participating medium. The former way of analysis is relatively simple whereas later one is complex in all aspects, i.e.., mathematically, numerically, physics, etc. Furthermore, the radiation problems can also be categories as diffuse and collimated beam radiation. The radiation problem from elevated temperature can be treated as diffuse radiation problem, whereas radiation energy traveling in a single direction belongs to collimated beam radiation category. The radiation problems from optics to biomedical field belong to collimated beam problem. The solar radiation is also an example of collimated beam radiation. 

The radiation heat transfer is modeled by an integrodifferential equation known as Radiative Transfer Equation (RTE). This equation represents radiation energy conservation in a direction. To achieve an accurate solution, one need to solve RTE numerically in many directions but need to limit the number of directions by keeping the computational resource in mind. Many numerical techniques have been developed to solve the RTE. The most popular technique is finite volume discrete ordinate method (FVDOM). Along with the CFD domain discretization, FVDOM also discretizes the angular domain of 4Pi. The angular domain discretization is regular using the spherical coordinate system with unit radius. This kind of angular discretization produces acceptable results for the diffuse radiation; however, getting right direction for the collimated beam radiation problems is little problematic. Thus FVDOM can not be used for the collimated beam problem in the present form. It is required to improve the angular discretization technique for the collimated beam problems. This project deals to improve the angular discretization so that FVDOM can be used with collimated beam radiation problems.

data.openings:
Ph.D. positions are available in the area of additive manufacturing techniques. Prospective students are encouraged to contact directly with a research proposal and CV.

Final year undergraduates looking for Project-Based Internships (3 - 6 months) are also welcome to apply.

Industry Project 

Worked on following different system of Aircraft Engine at General Electric (John F. Welch technology center Bangalore INDIA)

DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS 

CF34-10 Surface Cooler : Designed and analyzed the cross section of surface cooler in order to minimize weight and satisfy proof and burst pressure requirement.

Bleed Bias System: Modify existing system in order to meet fast sensitive system. 

Environment Control System: Developed Finite Element Model of the system and did vibration analysis (Harmonic analysis) to meet HCF requirement. 

Core Fire Suppression System: Developed Finite Element Model of the system and did vibration analysis (Harmonic analysis) to meet HCF requirement. 

IDG Cooling System: Developed Finite Element Model of the system and did static analysis in order to meet LCF requirement and vibration analysis (Harmonic analysis) to meet HCF requirement. 

VFSG Oil Tube System: Developed Finite Element Model of the system and did static analysis in order to meet LCF requirement and vibration analysis (Harmonic analysis) to meet HCF requirement. 



PRODUCTIVITY PROJECTS 

Developed MACROS (ANSYS) for stress analysis

Developed Correlation for damping estimation of ball joint

Developed a tool for predicting stress in bolt hole

Wrote Best practices (Best practice for HCF, Best practice for LCF, Best practice for thermal analysis)

Working on Fluid damping estimation project



PERFORMED ANALYSIS

Stress Analysis (Linear & Nonlinear)

Modal Analysis

Fatigue Analysis (HCF & LCF)

Damage Tolerance Analysis

Vibration Analysis (Harmonic Analysis & Spectrum Analysis) 

Thermal Analysis

data.interests: We have been working in the area of new multifunctional hybrid materials including metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), coordination polymers (CP) and metal-organic gels (MOGs) for energy storage and energy conversion applications. In addition, catalysis has been another core area of our interest. These catalysts/materials are developed through rational designs for strategic applications. We are also involved in integrating MOF/MOG based catalyst with electrospun fibers to render hybrid catalysts with balanced porosity, surface area and catalytic site for efficient energy applications.

data.interests:
• Characterization of aerosol climate forcing agents (black and brown carbon)
  • Coupling aerosol chemical speciation with receptor model-based source apportionment
  • Reconstruction of historical atmospheric pollutant deposition using lake sediments as archives
  • Population exposure to aerosols from residential biofuel use and related health effects

           

           For further details, please see my Research Group webpage: https://ac3group.wixsite.com/ac3group

data.experiences:
Dr. Shivang Shekhar specializes in Structural and Earthquake Engineering. Prior to joining academia, he has three years of industrial experience in Structural Engineering Design consultancy. His research focuses on the structural reliability assessment of civil infrastructure systems, under service loads and extreme events such as earthquakes. His research also emphasizes on assessing the impact of corrosion deterioration and design code evolution on the seismic vulnerability and loss assessment of bridges. His research encompasses nonlinear modeling and analysis of structures, probabilistic seismic risk and vulnerability assessment, life-cycle analysis of civil engineering structures, application of advanced machine learning algorithms for multi-dimensional fragility models, and uncertainty quantification in structural reliability problems.

Professional Experience 
  • Assistant Professor (August, 2020- May 2022) Department of Civil Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology & Science, Pilani - Hyderabad Campus
  • Senior Research Fellow (July, 2015- June, 2020) Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay

Administrative Responsibilities:

  • May 2019 - April 2022: Associate Dean (Infrastructure)

â€‹

Courses Taught or Currently Teaching:

  • CE607: Finite Element Analysis in Structural Engineering

  • CE555: Advanced Design of Structures

  • CE552: Concrete Technology

  • CE301: Strength of Materials and Structures

  • ME504: Numerical Methods for Engineering Computation

  • ME351: Management of Manufacturing and Logistics Systems

  • IC150P: Computation for Engineers Laboratory

  • IC140: Graphics for Design

 

Laboratories Developed:

  • Construction Materials Laboratory: The facility has been developed to support teaching, research and industry services. In addition to the basic quality control and characterization tests for concrete, cement, bitumen, aggregates, bricks and concrete blocks, the laboratory has state-of-the-art infrastructrue to support the testing of fibre reinforced concrete as per relevant ASTM and EN standards. The laboratory is currently being developed to support advanced thermal characterization of construction materials, testing of mass concrete, prestressing strands and NDT of steel and concrete structures.â€‹
  • Structural Analysis Laboratory: This is a UG teaching laboratory developed to demonstrate the structural behaviour of basic elements and systems. The experimental setups are equipped with sensors connected to desktop computers through dedicated data acquisition systems to facilitate the study of force and displacement responses.

data.interests:
• Developing experimental and computational tools to study the physical properties of thermoelectric materials and their utilization in making devices for waste heat recovery.
  • Use of density functional theory (DFT) based methods in improving the functionality of the existing functional materials and designing the technologically important new materials.
  • Understanding the basic physics of correlated electron systems and topological materials by using DFT, DFT+U, GW, DFT+DMFT, and GW+DMFT methods.

     Motto: Conducting quality research with minimum utilization of commercial equipment and commercial softwares.

data.experiences:
May 2017-Present: Assistant Professor, School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Mandi, India.

Dec 2016-Mar 2017: Post-Doctoral Research Associate at Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Illinois at Chicago.

Jan 2012-Dec 2016: Teaching and Research Assistant at Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Illinois at Chicago.
data.awards:
• Awarded with Litvin Graduate Honor Award (2014) in recognition of academic achievement and service to the department and graduate student community.

  • Awarded with Best Technical Merit Award for work on project, titled “Spinning Fibers Below 50 Nanometers” (2015) by The Nonwovens Institute in NWI-IAB consortium.

  • Lead Guest Editor in Special Issue on Recent Advances in Synthesis and Applications of Biopolymer Composites in Advances in Polymer Technology Journal (Wiley-Hindawi)

  • Awarded with Best Presentation Award (2019) at 3rd Young Researchers’ Symposium, held at IIT Delhi, May15-17, 2019.

  • Delivered invited talk on Ultrafine Polymer Nanofiber Nanotexture to Improve Nucleation Pool Boiling, at International Conference on Recent Advances in Fluid and Thermal Sciences (iCRAFT 2018), held at BITS-Pilani, Dubai Campus, Dec 05-07, 2018.

  • Scholarship from Govt. of India for all India ranking 68 in GATE 2011 (Entrance examination for Masters’ Studies in Indian Institute of Technology).

data.interests:
Dr. Mohammad Talha Research Group 

Computational Design Lab (CDL)

Dr. Talha research group (CDL), part of the School of Engineering, IIT Mandi 
applies theroy and computational simulation to accomplish new scientific 
understandings in order to explore technological innovations. 
Our research group administers computational modeling and 
simulation methods for problems ranging from 
continuum to the molecular scales.

Research Directions:

Dr. Talha has research interest in Computational Solid Mechanics and associated area. 

A) Computational Solid Mechanics:

  • Composite Structures, Functionally Graded Materials
  • Uncertainty quantification in Aircraft Analysis and Design
  • Imperfection sensitivity and initial geometric imperfections in Composites
  • Modeling of nano strucutres using non-local elasticity theory

B) Cardiovascular Computational Biomechanics:

  • Computational modeling of plaque development in the coronary arteries
  • Simulation and developement of Mock Circulation Loop

Other interactions and activities

  • Co-Organized a 3 day International workshop on "Climate change and extreme events - Himalaya" at IIT Mandi, April 18-20, 2019.
  • Organized a 3-day workshop on "Bio-Engineering Measures for Controlling Landslides and Geo-Environmental issues" by NIDM at IIT Mandi, Feb. 7-9, 2017 at IIT Mandi.
  • Organised a 1-day workshop on "Rainfall Induced Landslides: Mapping, Mitigations and Monitoring" Sponsored by SDMA at IIT Mandi, Oct., 11, 2017at IIT Mandi, sanction of 0.5 Lakhs.
  • Organised a 3-day workshop on “Landslides Mitigation by Modern Techniques” from 17-19 Feb., 2018 at HIPA Shimla.
  • Organized a 5-day capacity building workshop on Landslide Mitigation and DPR preparation by NDMA, New Delhi at IIT Mandi from 27-31 Aug., 2018.
  • Organized a 3-day capacity building workshop on Landslide Mitigation and DPR preparation by SDMA - HP, Shimla at IIT Mandi from 9-11 Oct., 2018.
  • Organized a 5-day capacity building workshop on Landslide Mitigation and DPR preparation by NDMA, New Delhi from 23-27 Sept., 2019.
  • Organized  a 3-day online workshop on Comprehensive landslide risk management with NIDM, New Delhi from 28-30 July, 2021

Other recognitions

  • CEO and Part time Director, Intiot Solutions Pvt Ltd., startup incubated by IIT Mandi Catalyst. 18 systems in Mandi, 3 systems in Dharampur, and 3 systems in Nainital, are installed through this company.

  • Constituted as member Corresponding Member of the International Technical Committee TC-208 on "Slope Stability in Engineering Practice" of the International Society for Soil Mechanics and Geotechnical Engineering (ISSMGE) for the term 2018-2021.

  • Constituted in the panel for Disaster Management for District, Kangra .(2020- Present)
